Mr Reed called at 10 O’Clock this morning, and I went with him first to the Office of Stephen Pleasonton fifth Auditor of the Treasury to remonstrate against his arbitrary attempt to cut down by a deduction of more than 4000 dollars the account of Mr Hammond—without allowing him even the right of petitioning Congress for allowance of the deduction— Pleasonton refusing to abide by the award of arbitrators, appointed by his own direction, had referred the Bill to some dependent of his own office who reduced it ad libitum and then reported to the Secretary of the Treasury the reduced bill, to be paid upon Hammond’s signing a receipt in full of all demands. Mr Woodbury directs another petty retrenchment, and orders the bill to be paid accordingly. I insisted that the whole bill ought to be paid according to the award of the referees, but Mr Reed only demanded what Hammond himself had brought his mind to consent to; that is that he should take the amount of the reduced Bill, reserving the right to petition Congress for the remainder— Pleasonton shuffled about this, till at last said he was willing, but the Secretary of the Treasury had directed otherwise— We then went to the Secretary himself, who told us that he had not examination of the case at-all; and that he had directed one small charge which he thought inadmissible to be struck out in all other respects had merely confirmed Pleasonton’s report and particuly in requiring a receipt in full of all demands from Hammond. That he had no objection to Hammond’s reserving the right to petition Congress, and would so direct if Pleasonton would write him a line advising it— We next returned to Pleasonton who shuffled again insisting that he had not recommended the exaction of the receipt in full, till at last he went and fetched the copy of his letter to the Secretary, and there it was in so many words— I almost lost my temper, and as Mr Hammond last evening had requested me to do spoke to him very plain— Reed teazed him to write the Letter to the Secretary which he had promised, and to which Woodbury had promised to conform, leaving to Hammond the right to Petition Congress, but he preferred making another trial to compromise and settle with Hammond himself—to which we agreed; but I told him if he did not agree with Hammond, it should go before Congress, for I would introduce it there— At the house, Thomas, Chairman of the Committee of Naval Affairs, called up the Bill appropriating upwards of 151000 dollars to pay the Navy pensions to be due on the first of next Month— The house went into Committee of the whole on the State of the Union— M’Kay in the Chair— The Speaker first called me to the Chair; but I asked him to excuse me; as I intended to address the Committee on the Bill. I did so, and opened a debate not soon to close— The Bill was reported to the House— Charles Shepard moved a second section, repealing the Navy Pension Act of 3. March 1837. which was carried by yeas and nays 81 to 70. and the bill passed.— Mr Wilcocks was here this Evening—

Mr Devlin a Clerk in Mr Pleasonton’s Office came this morning with a number of papers to explain to me his reasons for insisting on many deductions from Mr Hammond’s account, and to shew me the various estimates of different persons to whom he had referred them; all which he had already done yesterday— I told him that I had heard all this yesterday, and could not possibly judge of the correctness of estimates so widely differing from each other for the same thing— But that I had understood that Mr Pleasonton and Mr Hammond were to have agreed together and settled the account between them— He said that was what they proposed to do this day; but Mr Pleasonton was apprehensive that I might mention the subject in the house— I assured him I should not do this unless it should turn out that Mr Pleasonton and Mr Hammond finally disagreed about the settlement— At half past ten I attended the Meeting of the Committee of Manufactures— Present Adams, Nisbet, Tillinghast, Slade, Mitchell and Davis; absent Dromgoole, Worthington and Eastman— I brought the Bill for suppressing frauds on the revenue immediately before the Committee; and the report in the New-York Herald of the Meeting of the New-York Merchants, and the Speech of the Scotchman Robert Jaffray against the Bill— I read also Bennett’s remarks in the Herald upon the debate in the house of last Wednesday, and on the Letter then read in the house from Robert Jaffray to James Monroe— Bennett fiercely on the accuracy of the report, and defies Jaffray to his teeth.— Nisbet said that Bennett’s New-York Herald was utterly unworthy of credit, and he would not believe any charge contained in it against any man— Other members of the Committee were not so incredulous— They thought Mr Jaffray’s Letter a very equivocal denial— After some discussion upon the Bill Mr Slade moved that the Chairman be directed to report the House Bill of the last Session N. 100. as amended by the Senate without the Sections added by the Senate— This after some opposition from Nisbet was agreed to by the Committee and the question was postponed to the next Tuesday at half past ten, whether the Senate Bill should also be reported— When I entered the house I found them debating a motion by Giddings of Ohio, to reconsider the Section of the Navy pension appropriation Bill, repealing the Act of 3. March 1837—moved yesterday by Charles Shepard and carried— And the Bill actually so passed— This debate continued about an hour, and I took part in it— Shepard rose and began to reply when a message from the Senate announced the death of Felix Grundy, a member of that body from Tennessee—whereupon A. V. Brown pronounced the regular Eulogy upon him, and moved the crape-veiled Resolutions, and the immediate adjournment of the house—adopted of course— I went to the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures—drew up a short report on the falsified document, and assorted the papers for publication— At 4. p.m. I went to Mrs Hewitt’s and dined with Messrs. Daniel Webster and Edward Curtis. Mrs Webster, her niece Miss Le Roy, and Mrs Curtis—Governors Davis and Lincoln Saltonstall and Cushing were there— Home at 8. P.M.

Two Ladies whose names have escaped me, called this morning with a subscription paper, for a one dollar annual contribution for the poor of the foundery methodist church— They took the dollar as a donation.— A Mr Rudolph, came and informed me that he was from Boston— That he was poor, and had come and brought his family with him to get a place— He believed the Commissioner of public buildings had one to bestow, and he would thank me for a Letter of recommendation to that Officer— I told him I was not in that habit of recommending any person for Officer; and especially that I could not recommend any person with whom I had no acquaintance— I went to the Capitol an hour before the meeting of the house, and spent it in preparing the Bill for the more effectual collection of the revenue to be reported to the house; and I gave it with the draught of a report on the falsified document, to Mr Berry of the Clerk’s Office to be copied— At the meeting of the house, I asked leave to present the four Resolutions in relation to investments of public monies in the stocks of the States and the sales of such Stocks which I had prepared at the last Session of Congress, but which the house then refused to receive— No objection was now made to receiving them, and the Speaker was about taking the question upon their adoption when Cave Johnson objected and they were laid-over; with an order that they be printed— Samson Mason asked leave to introduce a Resolution of enquiry concerning the cost of certain Indian schools stipulated by Treaties—but Cave Johnson stopped that, as being out of order; insisting that Charles Shepard had the floor on the motion to reconsider the Section of the navy pension appropriation act which repeals the Act of 3. March 1837— Accordingly Shepard proceeded for about an hour, in a venomous, sophistical and unprincipled speech, in which he vented a long gathering burden of spleen against me, for which I had in readiness, a castigation which I shall not be allowed to administer; for after Shepard finished, several other members discussed and discoursed upon the act of 3. March 1837. almost without touching upon its real merits, till 3. O’Clock when Jameson of Missouri moved the previous Question; which cuts off my right of reply.— A motion was then made and carried to adjourn— Brockway has got up a subscription to print my Speech of Monday in a pamphlet— I called at the Office of the National Intelligencer and took from Mr Seaton a couple of copies of this day’s paper in which the Speech is reported by Wheeler—to revise it, which I was yet not able to do this Evening— Mr Seaton gave me a budget of Letters which he has received from Christopher Hughes at Stockholm, with injunction to communicate them to me— John Baer the buckeye blacksmith, and his brother James were here.

I had yesterday notified the members of the Committee on the falsified document, to meet this morning to consider the report that I had prepared to be presented to the house. Mr Dennis is gone home to keep the Christmas holidays, and Mr Barnard forgot my notification, so that M’Kay and Medill were my only associates at the meeting— In the discussion at the last Meeting upon the principles on which the report should be drawn up, I had proposed to touch upon the other mutilation of the document charged by judge Jay—upon the practice of allowing proof readers to depart from their copy, in the printing of public documents, upon the omission of one of the names of the 49 negroes in the translation of the Passport for the Ladinos of Ruiz, in the document from the Department of State, whence I inferred that it had been transmitted from the Department without being collated—to all which M’Kay and Medill had objected; and said it was not within the authority of the Committee; that they were charged only to report facts; and that all these circumstances to which I alluded might be very proper for a speech, and not for a report— I told them then what the consequence of their tight lacing would be; but I prepared the report according to their measure, simply stating the fact of falsification—and by whom it was committed—referring to the testimony, without one word of comment. It did not suit them— They wanted to acquit the proof reader of all bad intention and the house printers of all responsibility—the administration of all knowledge or participation in the wrong— I said if the report must give opinions, I could not forbear to pass censure upon all those parties— It came to be 12. O’Clock— They did not know whether to agree to the report or not. They would consult together and let me know.— M’Kay took the testimony which he afterwards returned to me in the house: but postponed telling me whether they would agree to my report or not— In the house numerous Bills from the Senate were twice read and referred—and Two Messages from the President, one of them the answer to my call for documents relating to China— I reported from the Committee of Manufactures for the more effectual collection of the revenue. Pickens attempted to prevent it from getting in; but failed— Referred to the Committee of the whole on the State of the Union.— I asked Jamieson to withdraw his motion for the previous question to enable me to reply to Charles Shepard— Jamieson refused— I appealed to the Justice of the house in vain— They sustained the previous question, and refused to reconsider.— A Letter form Rives, one from the house printers complained that the Clerk had given much of the house printing and binding to Langtree— After debate referred to a Select committee of 5.— States called through for Petitions. Debate on the burning of the Caroline. Attree’s Letter to me read— Monroe Adjourned after 3. over to Monday. Call at the Intelligencer Office. Seaton.
